headline: DeSantis cuts GOP priorities as he approves $110B budget
author: Lawrence Mower

But Smith ruled that the plan violated a 2010 state constitutional amendment  known as the Fair Districts amendment  that barred diminishing the ability of minority voters to elect representatives of their choice.

Ron DeSantis took a red pen to the states budget on Thursday, slashing some of the top priorities of Republican lawmakers on the way to approving a record $109.9 billion budget for the states upcoming fiscal year.
With the states top Republican leaders standing behind him on a stage in The Villages, DeSantis derided some of their spending as pork while announcing more than $3 billion in vetoes.
The cuts came despite the states booming budget, and despite Republican lawmakers delivering on a number of controversial DeSantis priorities this year, from immigration to voting.
Three of those vetoes were of spending projects for LGBTQ Floridians, including $150,000 in mental health services for survivors of the 2016 Pulse nightclub massacre in Orlando.

Smiths temporary injunction ordered use of a map that would keep the current sprawling shape of the district, which stretches from Jacksonville to west of Tallahassee.
DeSantis argued that continuing with such a district would involve racial gerrymandering and violate the Equal Protection Clause of the U.S. Constitution.
